Graphical abstract Cu nanoparticles generated in situ from molecular precursors constitute active and stable water reduction catalysts for long-term photocatalytic hydrogen production. Although largely neglected, convenient and commercially available copper salts constitute appropriate precursors for efficient and stable water reduction catalysts (WRC). Various copper salts have been applied in the photocatalytic proton reduction together with [Ir(ppy)2(bpy)]PF6 as photosensitizer (PS) and triethylamine (TEA) as electron donor. Among them, copper(I) iodide showed the best productivity, resulting in a TONCu of 260 and a stability of 4 days. The addition of 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy) led to a significant improvement of the catalytic system. Application of 2equiv. of bpy and an increased amount of PS improved the stability as well as the productivity (TONCu 711). Remarkably, this catalytic system was reactivated seven times with only further addition of fresh PS and TEA. Consequently, this copper-based WRC was shown to be active for more than 48 days reaching a maximum TONCu of >3900, which is in the same order of magnitude as previously known noble metal WRCs. Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM measurements revealed a part transformation of the molecularly-defined copper precursor into Cu containing nanoparticles of 5–10nm size. Additionally, by XAS measurements the conversion of the copper(I) salts into Cu(0) compounds under light irradiation was observed. With respect to low costs and high abundance of copper these WRCs are an appropriate alternative for noble metal based catalysts. Keywords Photocatalysis Water reduction Copper Nanoparticles Recycling 1 Introduction Renewable energies such as wind and sunlight contribute progressively to a sufficient and sustainable energy supply [1]. However, due to its fluctuating occurrence, the storage of electric energy becomes increasingly important. In this respect, various approaches for the interconversion of electric and chemical energy, e.g. by power to gas methods, are currently discussed. Here, hydrogen is of particular interest as a secondary energy carrier [1]. Hence, its generation from suitable starting materials, especially water, its storage and conversion back to electrical energy is a current topic of intensive research [1,2]. In fact, an increasing number of pilot plants combining wind mills or photovoltaic devices with classical water electrolysis are installed worldwide. Compared to the latter combination, possessing an overall efficiency between 10 and 14% [3], a more efficient way for the conversion of the sun's energy to hydrogen is desirable [4,5]. A possible solution would be the direct photocatalytic water splitting into hydrogen and oxygen. To improve the overall water splitting process, typically the two half reactions (water oxidation and water reduction) are studied separately employing sacrificial reagents as electron donors or electron acceptors [5,6]. In order to develop improved catalysts for this application, a general trend towards the usage of 3d metals is evident. Such catalysts would be of special advantage due to costs, abundance and toxicity compared to noble metals. Thus, significant efforts have been reported applying iron, cobalt and nickel complexes as water reduction catalysts (WRC) in the photocatalytic hydrogen generation from water [7]. Unfortunately, all these catalysts are either deactivated within a few days or require a huge excess of additional ligands to be stabilized. Molecularly-defined copper compounds have been largely neglected in photocatalytic water splitting despite their ability to act as catalysts for electrochemical water oxidation [8] and CO2 reduction [9]. On the other hand, heterogeneous cupric and cuprous oxides have been used as co-catalysts, mainly supported on titania [10], or as light harvesting semiconductors [11] for water reduction. Recently, homo- and heteroleptic copper complexes proved to be appropriate photosensitizers for the photocatalytic hydrogen production [12]. In addition, copper(I) polypyridine complexes showed interesting emission properties and therefore are considered as active components in organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), light-emitting electrochemical cells (LECs) or luminescence-based sensors [13]. As an extension of our previous work, we report herein the application of various copper salts as proton reduction catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting (Scheme 1 ). Interestingly, these molecularly-defined precursors are partly transformed during the water reduction reaction into highly active and stable nanoparticles. Consequently, this study contributes to the development of convenient and abundant copper WRCs and provides a deeper insight into their mode of operation. 2 Results and discussion Initially, we tested various copper(I) and copper(II) compounds as WRC with [Ir(ppy)2(bpy)]PF6 as photosensitizer (PS) in a THF/H2O mixture in the presence of triethylamine (SR=sacrificial reductant) (Table 1 ) [14]. Based on our previous experience regarding the influence of different ratios of THF, TEA and water the optimal conditions applying the same Ir-PS together with Fe3(CO)12 as WRC were chosen [15]. Our actual investigations included simple and commercially available copper salts as well as four different photosensitizers. Several copper(I) and copper (II) salts like triflate, acetate, chloride and [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 showed a limited activity in the range of 30–55 turnovers after 3h (Table 1, entries 1–6).It is noteworthy to mention that a number of catalysts are deactivated after 6–8h. Remarkably, only copper(I) iodide yielded a TON of more than 100 after 3h (Table 1, entry 7). Both, copper(I) and copper(II) compounds were active in the water reduction. Using copper(II) acetate as precursor the TON was almost twice as high as for copper(I) acetate after 3h (Table 1, entries 3 and 4). However, no influence of the initial copper oxidation state onto the activity could be observed in the case of chloride salts (Table 1, entries 5 and 6). Due to the reducing conditions applied here, a conversion of copper(II) into copper(I) cannot be excluded. Additionally, the influence of the iodide counter ion on the activity was exemplarily studied according to the high activity of copper iodide (Table 1, entry 7). While the addition of an iodide source (i.e. KI) to copper(II) acetate initially had a detrimental effect, for copper(II) triflate an increase of the TON by a factor of 1.4 after 3h and 1.7 after 20h, respectively, was observed (Table 1, entries 8 and 9). However, the productivity of CuI could not be achieved. For comparison, also commercially available copper oxides and Cu core/CuO shell nanoparticles were tested. These samples resulted in poor to medium productivities (Table 1, entries 10–13). Among them, the best result was achieved with CuO nanoparticles (Table 1, entry 12 and Fig. S2-1), reaching approximately 30% of the TON of CuI. The higher activity of CuI is most likely due to the lower reduction potential of CuI (0.00V vs. SHE) for CuI2 − +e− →Cu+2 I− compared to 0.521V for Cu+ +e− →Cu) [16]. On the basis of these results we chose CuI for further experiments. First, we tested other photosensitizers which had shown good performances in our previous investigations (Fig. 1 ) [6a–c, 12c and d]. Among them the [Ir(2,5-dpo)2(4-Ph-bpy)]PF6 (PS2) gave the best result, almost comparable to [Ir(ppy)2(bpy)]PF6 (Table 1, entry 14). Application of [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 (PS3) resulted in no hydrogen evolution (Table 1, entry 15). [Cu(2,9-di-n-butyl-4,7-diphenyl-1,10-phenanthroline) (10,10′-(2,8-dimethyl-phen-oxathiine-4,6-diyl)bis(2,8-dimethyl-10Hphen-oxaphos-phinine))][PF6] (PS4) deactivated already after 3h (Table 1, entry 16). Working without a cut-off filter caused almost the same initial activities. However, a faster deactivation was observed. Whereas application of a 420nm cut-off filter significantly decreased the catalytic performance. This can be explained by the removal of the most relevant wavelengths for the excitation of PS1 from the light beam (Table 1, entries 7, 17 and 18; UV–vis spectrum of PS1 in Fig. S3). Additionally, it was shown that both, the PS as well as the WRC, were essential to drive the reaction (Table 1, entries 19 and 20). Solely, the Ir-PS1 alone showed some minimal activity which levelled off after 18h. Interestingly, the performance of the photocatalytic system was significantly improved by the addition of organic ligands. Therefore, various mono- and multidentate nitrogen as well as phosphorous containing ligands were tested (Table 2 ). The reaction time has been elongated up to 96h, since the positive influence of ligands is expected to improve especially the long-term stability of the overall system. Within 96h a TON of 260 has been achieved with PS1 and CuI in the absence of any additional ligand (Table 2, entry 1). While the addition of 2equiv. of either triphenylphosphine (PPh3), bis(diphenyl-phosphino)ethane (dppe), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), pyridine or bathocuproinedisulfonic acid disodium salt (BC(SO3Na)2), resulted in less stable systems (Table 2, entries 2, 3, 5, 6 and 10), N 1,N 1,N 2,N 2-tetramethylethane-1,2-diamine (tmeda, 2equiv.), 3equiv. of pyridine and 2,2′:6,2″-terpyridine (tpy, 2equiv.) led to almost same activities after 20h as observed without additional ligand present (Table 2, entries 4, 7 and 9). However, only in the latter case a slight stabilization effect was observed after 96h. The best performance was achieved applying 2equiv. of 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy, Table 2, entry 8) leading to a TON of 241 after 20h and 470 after 96h, respectively. A further improvement could be obtained with an increased amount of PS1. Therewith, TON's of 558 after 96h and 711 after 144h, respectively, were observed (Table 2, entry 11). Thus, the productivity was finally improved up to 273% compared to pure CuI. Noteworthy, this photocatalytic system was active for more than 6 days (Fig. S2-3). Lowering the amount of NEt3 resulted in significant decrease of catalyst productivity despite less than half of the amine is consumed after 96h (Table 2, entry 12). Finally, the molecularly-defined complex [Cu(bpy)2]I2 was tested for comparison, which showed 84% activity compared to the in situ system (Table 2, entry 13). Next, we were interested in the optimum amount of 2,2′-bipyridine ligand with respect to copper. Therefore, an additional set of experiments was performed using 1, 3 or 5equiv. of bpy (Fig. 2 ). In agreement with the previous observations, the stabilizing effect became more evident after longer reaction times. In accordance, a pronounced effect of the different amounts of bpy was observed only after 20h when the presence of bpy became advantageously. Finally, after 96h the sample with 2equiv. bpy showed the best performance (Fig. 2). Besides the choice of copper precursors and ligands, also the amount of the solvents/TEA mixture had a significant influence on the overall activity. Applying the same quantities of PS1 (15μmol) and CuI/bpy (10/20μmol), both, working with more concentrated as well as more diluted solutions (5mL, 20mL and 40mL THF:NEt3:H2O 3:2:1, volume based, respectively) yielded much lower hydrogen amounts than with 10mL THF:NEt3:H2O (3:2:1, volume based) (Fig. 3 ). Based on all these results incident photon to hydrogen efficiencies (IPHE) of up to 15.1±3.5% and 15.1±2.7% at wavelengths of 415nm and 440nm, respectively, were measured under optimized conditions (30μmol PS1, 10μmol CuI, 20μmol bpy, 0.125W Hg-irradiation by Lumatec Superlite 400 [18] via optical fibre cable, S4). These IPHE values are within the range of previously reported efficiencies for comparable iridium photosensitizers applying other WRC [6b and c,15,19,20]. Especially during the course of longer reactions, we observed the formation of a black precipitate. In order to obtain more information about the nature of this deposit and possible deactivation pathways, we performed aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM (high angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy) and EDXS investigations. This is the only method that allows visualizing single atoms on different supports as recently described [21]. Therefore, the components were dissolved in 10mL, 20mL or 40mL of THF:NEt3:H2O 3:2:1, respectively, resulting in different initial molar concentrations of PS1 (0.375, 0.75 and 1.5mM), CuI (0.25, 0.50 and 1.0mM) and bpy (0.5, 1.0 and 2.0mM), respectively. For analysis, the reaction mixtures were investigated after set times of irradiation. Surprisingly in all investigated samples, Cu containing particles with sizes between 5 and 10nm were detected that were decorated with Ir containing particles of 1–2nm on their surface. (Fig. 4a–c). Depending on the molar concentration, differences occurred with respect to the number of precipitated Ir particles on the Cu nanoparticles, as well as in the composition of the surrounding diffuse area. According to an EDX map, the latter contained Ir and Cu in different ratios and especially in the beginning also iodine (Fig. 5 and Fig. S5-1). For the lowest concentration (0.375mM PS1, 0.25mM CuI, 0.5mM bpy), samples were investigated after 50.5, 67 and 116h of reaction. Surprisingly, after 50.5h the Cu containing Ir decorated particles were observed (Fig. 4a). Furthermore, in the outer part and the surrounding diffuse area iodide as well as Ir and Cu were detected. Thus, CuI seemed to remain at least partly in solution. With ongoing illumination time (67h, Fig. 4b) much less iodide was detected in the diffuse area and in solution. After 116h, copper and iridium as well as the Cu/Ir nanoparticles were observed, but no traces of iodide could be detected in the surrounding diffuse area. At this stage, the catalyst system showed no further activity. An increased molarity (0.75mM PS1, 0.5mM CuI, 1.0mM bpy) led to the same general observations (Fig. 4c and Fig. S5-1a). However, more Ir containing particles were deposited on the Cu nanoparticles. This finding is also consistent with a TEM performed after 96h for an active system at even higher molar concentration (1.5mM PS1, 1.0mM CuI, 2.0mM bpy). In this case, the Cu containing particles (5–10nm) were detected (Fig. 4d and Fig. S5-1b) along with an increased number of the Ir containing particles. In addition, bigger, agglomerated, as well as non-agglomerated Cu containing nanoparticles, with and without Ir clusters, and non-supported Ir particles were all observed. In both cases of higher concentrations again Cu and Ir were detected by EDX (Fig. 5 and Fig. S5-1b) in the diffuse area. This indicates a part transformation of the original molecularly-defined copper complex towards copper oxide and/or metallic nanoparticles after longer reaction times. Besides, the photosensitizer is deactivated during the course of reaction [19] and deposited as Ir nanoparticles on the surface of the copper support. Further insight into the role of the ligand was provided by a TEM measurement of a reaction mixture in the absence of 2,2′-bipyridine. Here, bigger Cu nanoparticles are formed (17–50nm) also containing Ir clusters. Thus, in the presence of bpy smaller and more stable particles are formed [22]. Due to its role as a chelating ligand, bpy also serves as potential stabilizer of PS1 and retards its deactivation. In order to get more information about the nature of the copper containing nanoparticles X-ray absorption experiments were performed. For these measurements the sample contained a sixfold concentration of CuI and bpy compared to standard catalytic investigations in order to obtain a reasonable signal to noise ratio especially for the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) measurements were performed before, during and after irradiation by a Lumatec Superlite 400 [18] light source. A copper foil, cuprous and cupric oxides were employed as references. XANES measurements before light irradiation of the reaction solution containing CuI, bpy and IrPS in THF/TEA/water (3:2:1 volume based) revealed a mixture of both Cu(II) and Cu(I) metal centres (Fig. 6 ; curve a). Obviously, the hydrolysis of the CuI led to a part oxidation of the copper(I). During the first few minutes of irradiation a clear shift of the absorption edge to lower energies occurred. This indicated a reduction of the oxidic Cu to a stable metallic copper, since after finishing the irradiation, i.e. after 120min, no further significant changes in the XANES structure were observed (Fig. 6; curves b and c). Further insights into the structural changes of the copper containing components were obtained by EXAFS analysis (Fig. 7 and fitting results along with structure parameters in S6). Due to gas bubble generation that led to additional noise, EXAFS measurements were performed only before and after light irradiation. Applying the same reaction solutions used for XANES before the irradiation, no evidence for CuI bonds were found. Only CuO bonds were detected, which slightly differed from the CuO interaction known from solid CuO or Cu2O. In the first coordination shell Cu is surrounded by nearly four equidistant O atoms. After irradiation only CuCu bonds were observed, clearly showing the formation of metallic copper nanoparticles. In summary, both XANES and EXAFS, confirm the formation of the metallic Cu nanoparticles during irradiation. Simultaneously with the formation of the metallic Cu, bubbling in the capillary was observed indicating the formation of hydrogen. Intending on the stability of the formed copper nanoparticles, their long-term catalytic activity was evaluated by recycling experiments. Therefore, only fresh PS1 was added every 6 days to the reaction mixture (Fig. 8 ). Eight runs, including seven restarts, were exemplarily performed resulting in an unprecedented TON of >3900 and a WRC lifetime of >48 days. For the sixth run 3.33mL of NEt3 also had to be added in addition to the PS due to complete consumption of the sacrificial reagent. While the overall productivity of the first run was obviously dominated by the mixture of homogeneous CuI and copper nanoparticles starting from the second run the latter should have become dominant and the productivity is dependent on the availability of intact PS and the concentration of TEA. As shown before, a lower TEA concentration led to a lower catalyst performance (Table 2, entry 12). In consequence, productivity comparable to the second run was restored in the sixth run by addition of fresh PS and TEA. The performance of the catalyst species generated from CuI and bpy in all eight runs was higher compared to the tested commercially available copper oxide nanoparticles. TEM measurements, performed after the eighth run, revealed the presence of the expected copper nanoparticles with Ir cluster decoration. However, despite the very long reaction times single Cu and Ir atoms were still observed (Fig. S5-2). 3 Conclusion We have shown that starting from convenient and inexpensive copper salts active and stable water reduction catalysts can be easily generated. A significant improvement of the catalyst performance was achieved through the addition of nitrogen ligands such as 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy). Applying 2equiv. of bpy and an increased amount of PS led to strongly improved stability and productivity (6 days, TONCu =711). Remarkably, this catalytic system can be reactivated several times. Within eight runs a TONCu of more than 3900 and stable operation for more than 48 days were observed. This is already in the same order of magnitude as previously known noble metal WRCs. Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM measurements revealed a part transformation of the molecularly-defined copper precursor into Cu nanoparticles of 5–10nm size. Additionally, by XAS measurements the conversion of the copper(I) salts into copper(0) compounds under light irradiation was observed. With respect to low costs and high abundance of copper these WRC are an appropriate alternative for noble metal based catalysts. The beneficial role of bpy was also assessed by TEM studies showing the formation of smaller nanoparticles during the course of reaction. Consequently, this study contributes to the development of abundant copper WRCs in the future. 4 Experimental 4.1 General methods All catalytic experiments were carried out under an argon atmosphere with exclusion of air. THF, TEA, and doubly distilled water were degassed and purified by standard laboratory methods prior to use. Cuprous and cupric oxides, CuO and Cu(core)/CuO(shell) nanoparticles, copper salts and complexes as well as phosphorus and nitrogen containing ligands and [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 were purchased from commercial suppliers. The iridium photosensitizers PS1 [20] and PS2 [6c], the copper photosensitizer PS4 [10c] and [Cu(bpy)2]I2 [24] were synthesized according to literature procedures. The detailed synthesis procedure as well as the analytical data of the complex are provided in the SI. 4.2 Typical procedure for light-driven water reduction A double-walled thermostatically controlled reaction vessel was thoroughly evacuated and purged with argon. The photosensitizer and copper WRC were added as solids. Then, the corresponding solvent mixture (THF/TEA/H2O, 3:2:1, volume based) was added and the system was adjusted to 25°C before switching on the light source. Finally, the photocatalytic reaction was started by the introduction of light onto the reaction vessel. The amount of gas liberated was measured either by an automatic or manual gas burette. Details on the equipment and the experimental setup have been published previously [6a–c]. The relative composition of the evolved gas was determined by GC (gas chromatograph HP 6890N, carboxen 1000, TCD, external calibration). The applied light sources were a 300W Xe-lamp (Lot-Oriel) [14b] or a Hg-vapor light source (Lumatec) [18]. All given values were the averages of at least two experiments. The variation of the volumes for reproduction experiments with gas evolution ≥10mL was between 1 and 20%, if not stated otherwise. 4.3 Transmission electron microscopy The TEM measurements were performed at 200kV with an aberration-corrected JEM-ARM200F (JEOL, Corrector: CEOS). The microscope is equipped with a JED-2300 (JEOL) energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDXS) for chemical analysis. The aberration-corrected STEM imaging high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) was performed under the following conditions. Both, HAADF and EDXS were performed with a spot size of approximately 0.1nm, probe current of 120pA, a convergence angle of 30–36° and collection semi-angles for HAADF 90–170 mrad [25]. The samples were prepared from freshly prepared reaction mixtures. After certain hours of light irradiation a droplet of the reaction mixture was placed on a holey carbon supported Ni-grid mesh 300, dried and transferred to the microscope. 4.4 X-ray absorption spectroscopy The X-ray absorption experiments were performed at the Cu K-edge (8979eV) at the BM23 beamline at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF, Grenoble). Monochromatic X-ray beam was obtained from the white beam by using Si(111) double crystal; a harmonic rejection has been performed using Si coated mirrors. Both the incident (I 0) and transmitted (I 1) monochromatic beam intensities were measured by using ionic chambers filled with 1.7bar N2 and 0.3bar Ar, respectively, and eventually the chambers filled up to 2bar with He. The photon energy was calibrated with the edge energy obtained from the maxima first derivative of the Cu K-edge in the Cu foil (8984eV). The reference samples (Cu foil, Cu2O and CuO) were measured in transmission mode. For the liquid samples (CuI before, during and after the radiation with visible light) the EXAFS measurements were performed in fluorescence mode with a 13-element Ge detector (Canberra Industries). The concentrations of the components present in the liquid sample were: 15μmol Ir-PS1, 60μmol CuI and 120μmol bpy in 10mL THF, TEA, H2O (3:2:1 volume based). For the experiments the liquid solution was filled into quartz capillaries with a diameter of 2mm and wall thickness of 0.01mm. As light source a Lumatec Superlite 400 (filter 2: 400–500nm, light output 1.5W) was used. The EXAFS parts of the spectra were collected with a variable sampling step in energy with Δk =0.05Å−1 up to 10Å−1. The extraction of χ(k) function has been done using Athena and EXAFS data analysis has been performed with Artemis software. [26]. Fourier transform of EXAFS function χ(k) into R space with k 2 weighted factor and Kaiser-Bessel window function has been performed in 2–10Å−1, yielding a function |χ(R)| (Å−3). coredata.dc:description: Although largely neglected, convenient and commercially available copper salts constitute appropriate precursors for efficient and stable water reduction catalysts (WRC). Various copper salts have been applied in the photocatalytic proton reduction together with [Ir(ppy)2(bpy)]PF6 as photosensitizer (PS) and triethylamine (TEA) as electron donor. Among them, copper(I) iodide showed the best productivity, resulting in a TONCu of 260 and a stability of 4 days. The addition of 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy) led to a significant improvement of the catalytic system. Application of 2equiv. of bpy and an increased amount of PS improved the stability as well as the productivity (TONCu 711). Remarkably, this catalytic system was reactivated seven times with only further addition of fresh PS and TEA. Consequently, this copper-based WRC was shown to be active for more than 48 days reaching a maximum TONCu of >3900, which is in the same order of magnitude as previously known noble metal WRCs. Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM measurements revealed a part transformation of the molecularly-defined copper precursor into Cu containing nanoparticles of 5–10nm size. Additionally, by XAS measurements the conversion of the copper(I) salts into Cu(0) compounds under light irradiation was observed. With respect to low costs and high abundance of copper these WRCs are an appropriate alternative for noble metal based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Copper-based water reduction catalysts for efficient light-driven hydrogen generation
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
